Feeding.title: Avoid overfeeding
Feeding.content: Obesity leads to joint problems and diabetes. Follow portion guidelines based on weight and activity level.

Feeding.title: No human junk food
Feeding.content: Chocolate, grapes, onions, and artificial sweeteners (like xylitol) are toxic to dogs.

Feeding.title: Regular meal schedule
Feeding.content: Helps with digestion and prevents begging behavior.

Feeding.title: Slow feeding for fast eaters
Feeding.content: Use a slow-feeder bowl to prevent bloating and choking.

Feeding.title: Fresh water is a must
Feeding.content: Change water at least twice a day to keep them hydrated.

Grooming.title: Regular brushing prevents shedding mess
Grooming.content: Short-haired dogs need weekly brushing; long-haired breeds may need daily brushing.

Grooming.title: Bath once a month (or as needed)
Grooming.content: Too many baths strip natural oils, causing dry skin.

Grooming.title: Trim nails every 3-4 weeks
Grooming.content: Overgrown nails can cause pain and affect posture.

Grooming.title: Clean ears regularly
Grooming.content: Especially for floppy-eared dogs prone to infections.

Grooming.title: Use dog-specific shampoo
Grooming.content: Human shampoos can irritate their skin due to different pH levels.

Training.title: Start training early
Training.content: Puppies learn faster, but older dogs can still be trained with patience.

Training.title: Positive reinforcement works best
Training.content: Reward good behavior with treats and praise instead of punishment.

Training.title: Be consistent with commands
Training.content: Use the same words like 'sit' and 'stay' to avoid confusion.

Training.title: Socialization is key
Training.content: Expose dogs to different people, sounds, and places early on to prevent fear and aggression.

Feeding.title: Cats are obligate carnivores
Feeding.content: They need meat-based food for proper nutrition.

Feeding.title: Dry food isn’t enough
Feeding.content: Include wet food to keep them hydrated and prevent urinary problems.

Feeding.title: Small, frequent meals mimic nature
Feeding.content: Cats naturally eat multiple small meals a day instead of two large ones.

Feeding.title: Avoid milk
Feeding.content: Despite common belief, most cats are lactose intolerant.

Feeding.title: Feeding in a quiet place
Feeding.content: Cats feel more comfortable eating in a calm, stress-free area.

Grooming.title: Cats groom themselves, but brushing helps
Grooming.content: It reduces shedding and prevents hairballs.

Grooming.title: Avoid frequent baths
Grooming.content: Cats rarely need baths unless dirty or prescribed by a vet.

Grooming.title: Trim claws every 2-3 weeks
Grooming.content: This prevents furniture damage and keeps their paws healthy.

Grooming.title: Clean their ears gently
Grooming.content: Use a damp cotton ball, but don’t go too deep.

Grooming.title: Provide scratching posts
Grooming.content: Helps maintain claw health and prevents furniture damage.

Training.title: Use treats and praise
Training.content: Cats respond best to positive reinforcement.

Training.title: Litter box training is easy
Training.content: Just place them in the box after meals, and they usually learn quickly.

Training.title: Discourage bad behavior gently
Training.content: Redirect instead of punishing (e.g., use a scratching post instead of scolding for clawing furniture).

Training.title: Clicker training works for cats too
Training.content: Reward them with treats when they respond to commands.

Training.title: Routine builds trust
Training.content: Cats prefer predictability, so train at the same time daily.
